Tawurji, Tradisi Unik Rebutan Uang Koin dari Cirebon
01 Nov 2019, 10:11 by Sudirman Wamad


Tradisi Tawurji khas Cirebon (Sudirman/detikcom)

Cirebon - Masyarakat Kota Cirebon berbondong-bondong menyerbu Keraton Kanoman demi mengikuti tradisi Tawurji. Keseruan rebutan uang koin jadi magnet tradisi itu.Keluarga Keraton Kanoman Cirebon dan masyarakat ramai-ramai menyanyikan sepenggal bait yang berisi doa, penanda tradisi Tawurji dimulai."Ji tawur ji, tawur. Selamat dawa umur. Tawurji!,"Keluarga Keraton Kanoman Cirebon langsung melempar koin usai menyanyikan sepenggal bait tersebut. Masyarakat yang saat itu tengah berkumpul di depan Bangsal Jinem Keraton Kanoman Cirebon langsung berebut koin. Mereka rela saling dorong, merangkak demi mendapatkan koin.Juru bicara Keraton Kanoman Cirebon Ratu Raja Arimbi Nurtina mengatakan tradisi Tawurji merupakan media sedekah keluarga keraton."Ini menunjukkan bahwa salah satu sifat manusia itu harus bersedekah. Kami memiliki cara sendiri, yang mana itu melalui Tawurji," kata Arimbi kepada awak media usai tradisi Tawurji di Keraton Kanoman Cirebon, Jawa Barat, Rabu (30/10/2019).


Foto: Sudirman Wamad/detikcom

Arimbi menceritakan tradisi Tawurji lahir dari rahim rasa saling gotong royong. Pada zaman dulu, lanjut dia, para fakir miskin memohon pertolongan kepada orang kaya, yang sudah mapan. Fakir miskin tersebut memohon sembari membacakan doa Tawurji. "Berharap sedekahnya itu bisa bermanfaat dan barokah. Sehingga, memberikan sebagian kecil hartanya untuk orang-orang yang membutuhkan," kata Arimbi.Arimbi mengatakan tradisi Tawurji selalui dilakukan pada Rabu terakhir bulan Safar. Selain Tawurji, Keraton Kanoman juga menggelar tradisi Ngapem. Keluarga keraton membuat kue apem yang kemudian dibagikan ke masyarakat.


Foto: Sudirman Wamad/detikcom

Salah seorang warga, Iva (30) rela saling dorong demi mendapatkan uang koin. Iva mengaku baru pertama kali mengikuti tradisi Tawurji. "Mencari berkahnya. Karena katanya, uang koinyang disawerkan itu didoakan dulu oleh sultan dan rombongannya," kata Iva.Iva menambahkan sedikit atau banyaknya uang koin yang ia dapat, bukanlah yang utama. Berkah tradisi Tawurji lah yang membuat Iva antusias. "Memang ini tradisi tahun, dari tahun ke tahun. Tapi baru tahun ini saya ikut," kata Iva. Tawurji, a unique tradition of fighting for coins from Cirebon
Nov 01 2019, 10:11 by Sudirman Wamad


Cirebon Tawurji Tradition (Sudirman / detikcom)

Cirebon - Cirebon City people flocked to the Kanoman Palace to follow the Tawurji tradition. The excitement over coins became a magnet for the tradition. The family of the Kanoman Palace of Cirebon and the people in the crowd sang a fragment of the temple containing prayers, the Tawurji tradition marker began. "Ji tawur ji, tawur. Happy age. Tawurji!" flip a coin after singing a piece of the verse. The people who were gathering in front of the Jinem Ward in the Cirebon Kanoman Palace immediately competed for coins. They are willing to push each other, crawl to get a coin. Keraton Kanoman Cirebon spokesperson Ratu Raja Arimbi Nurtina said the Tawurji tradition is a media for family charity. "This shows that one of human nature must be charitable. We have our own way, which is through Tawurji , "said Arimbi to the media crew after the Tawurji tradition at the Kanoman Palace in Cirebon, West Java, Wednesday (10/30/2019).


Photo: Sudirman Wamad / detikcom

Arimbi tells the tradition of Tawurji was born from the womb of mutual cooperation. In ancient times, he continued, the needy begged for help from the rich, who were already well-established. The poor man begged while reciting the Tawurji prayers. "Hoping that alms can be beneficial and blessing. So, giving a small portion of his wealth to people in need," said Arimbi .rimbi said the Tawurji tradition was always carried out on the last Wednesday of the month of Safar. Besides Tawurji, Kanoman Palace also held Ngapem tradition. The royal family made apem cakes which were then distributed to the community.


Photo: Sudirman Wamad / detikcom

One resident, Iva (30) is willing to push each other to get coins. Iva claimed that this was the first time she had followed the Tawurji tradition. "Looking for his blessings. Because he said, the coins which were handed over were prayed first by the sultan and his entourage," said Iva. Iva added that little or how much coins he got, was not the main thing. It was the blessing of the Tawurji tradition that made Iva enthusiastic. "Indeed this is a tradition of the year, from year to year. But only this year I participated," said Iva.
